name: Black vs 1. d4 (Complete Slav Repertoire)
description: A complete 1.d4 repertoire based on the Slav Defense. The key concept: develop the light-squared bishop to f5 BEFORE playing e6, but only AFTER securing the center with dxc4. Covers Queen's Gambit, London System, Catalan, Trompowsky, Colle, and all major White tries.

tree.explanation: The Queen's Pawn Opening. White takes central control and prepares c4.

children.explanation: We contest the center immediately! This is the classical response, leading to solid, strategically rich positions.
The Queen's Gambit! White attacks our d5 pawn. Despite the name, it's not a true gambit - taking on c4 doesn't win a pawn permanently.
The Slav Defense! We defend d5 with a pawn while keeping the c8-bishop's diagonal OPEN. This is better than 2...e6 which traps the bishop. Our plan: play ...dxc4 first, THEN ...Bf5.
The most common move. White develops naturally.
We develop and attack e4. Now White must decide their setup.
The main line. White pressures d5. Now comes the critical decision...
THE CLASSICAL SLAV! We capture first, gaining control of b3 (preventing Qb3). NOW we can safely play ...Bf5. This move order is critical!
White prevents ...b5, stopping us from holding the c4 pawn. This is the main line.
NOW the bishop comes out! With c4 captured, Qb3 no longer attacks both b7 and d5. This is the whole point of our move order.
White prepares to recapture on c4 with the bishop.
NOW we play e6 - AFTER the bishop is already developed! We complete our solid setup.
White recaptures the pawn.
We develop actively, pinning the knight. The a4 pawn weakened b4!
White castles.
We develop the knight to a flexible square. It can go to b6 or support ...e5 or ...c5 breaks.
White prepares e4.
We retreat the bishop to a safe square where it remains active.
White seizes the center.
We castle to safety. A typical Classical Slav middlegame. Black will play for ...c5 or ...e5 breaks.
White offers to trade bishops.
We trade. The position is balanced with mutual chances.
White recaptures.
We prepare ...e5! Black has a solid position and good counterplay.
White attacks our bishop! This is a key idea in the Slav.
We castle calmly. If Nxf5 exf5, we get the e-file and a strong pawn on f5.
White takes the bishop pair.
We recapture. The f5 pawn is strong, we have the e-file, and our position is very solid.
An ambitious try. White wants Nxc4 with a powerful knight.
We challenge the knight!
White recaptures with the knight - very active placement.
We prepare ...e5! The knight on c4 can be challenged.
White fianchettoes.
The key break! We gain space and activity.
The Geller Gambit! White sacrifices a pawn for rapid development.
We hold the pawn! Critical position.
White kicks our knight.
The knight finds a great outpost. Black keeps the pawn with a good game.
A quiet approach, planning to recapture on c4.
We can try to hold the pawn! White must work to recover it.
White undermines our chain.
We push! If Nb1 (or Na2), we've disrupted White's development.
The knight is awkwardly placed.
We complete development. Black has an extra pawn and good play - this is the Noteboom-style position.
PREMATURE! This looks natural but has a serious flaw. White can exploit the weak b7 pawn.
White exchanges.
We must recapture.
THE PROBLEM! White attacks BOTH b7 and d5. This is why we should have played 4...dxc4 first!
The sad retreat. We must guard b7. Our bishop wasted two tempi.
A modern gambit! We sacrifice b7 for rapid development and activity.
White takes.
We develop and trap the queen! After Qb3 Rb8 Qd1 e5, Black has excellent compensation.
The queen escapes.
We activate the rook with tempo!
Queen retreats.
We seize the center! Black has full compensation for the pawn - active pieces and central control.
The Semi-Slav. Very solid but the bishop is now locked behind the pawns. Still a reputable choice with rich theory.
White develops solidly.
Heading for the Meran Variation with ...dxc4 and ...b5.
White develops.
We take, preparing ...b5.
White recaptures.
The Meran! We gain space and prepare ...Bb7.
White retreats the bishop.
We fianchetto! The bishop is active on the long diagonal. Complex play ahead.
The Anti-Meran! Sharp and double-edged.
We ask the bishop to decide.
White takes, doubling our pawns but giving us the bishop pair.
We recapture with the queen. The bishop pair is valuable in this open position.
The Chebanenko Slav! We secure b5 and avoid Qb3 problems. Very flexible.
White develops.
We expand! Now ...Bb7 is coming.
White prepares Bb2.
We develop actively! The bishop is outside the pawn chain. Flexible position.
White fixes the queenside. Space advantage but less flexibility.
We prepare ...e5! breaking the center.
A slower approach. White may transpose to Colle-like setups.
Without Nc3, we CAN play Bf5 immediately! Qb3 doesn't work because d5 is defended by the c6 pawn.
White develops.
We complete our solid setup. Bishop is out, position is rock-solid.
White attacks our bishop. This is the main try.
We retreat. The bishop is still active on g6.
White trades.
We recapture, opening the h-file for our rook! Black has counterplay on the kingside.
White develops.
We can trade, simplifying. Or keep the bishop with Bg6.
White recaptures.
Solid position. We've achieved our goal - the bishop developed before e6.
White prevents ...Bf5 by controlling the square. A solid system.
We fianchetto instead! The bishop will go to f5 via g7-e6 or simply to g7.
White develops.
We develop anyway!
White tries the Qb3 idea.
We offer a queen trade! After Qxb6 axb6, we have easy equality.
Immediate Qb3, pressuring b7 and d5.
We take! Now Qxc4 allows normal development.
White recaptures.
We develop! The position is comfortable for Black.
A Catalan-style setup against the Slav.
We develop the bishop! The fianchetto doesn't prevent this.
White completes the fianchetto.
We solidify. Black is very comfortable.
Knight first - often transposes to main lines.
Natural development. 4.Nf3 transposes to main lines.
Transposes to main line.
Classical Slav! Same as main lines.
Independent line - White avoids Nf3 for now.
We can go Semi-Slav here, or...
Chebanenko setup - securing b5.
We can take immediately too!
Preventing b5.
Bishop comes out! Same idea.
Geller Gambit territory.
We hold the pawn!
The Exchange Slav. White simplifies early - often considered drawish but playable for both sides.
We recapture. Symmetrical pawn structure.
White develops.
We develop.
White develops the bishop actively.
We develop. Heading for a completely symmetrical position.
White prepares Bd3.
We mirror! Completely symmetrical. White has first move advantage but Black is rock-solid.
White develops.
We trade. Equal game.
White recaptures.
We solidify. Completely equal position.
Preparing ...Bf5 with ...b5 options.
White develops.
Bishop out, solid position.
White develops.
We develop the bishop!
White develops.
Natural development.
Transposes to main Exchange lines.
Bishop comes out!
An interesting try to avoid the symmetrical positions.
We develop. If Bxf6, we get the bishop pair.
White doubles our pawns but we get the bishops.
We recapture toward the center. The bishop pair compensates for the doubled pawns.
The Queen's Gambit Declined. Very solid but the light-squared bishop is locked behind the pawns. A respectable alternative.
White develops.
We develop.
The main line. White pins our knight.
We break the pin. Classical and solid.
White develops.
We castle. Heading for the Tartakower or Lasker variations.
Flexible development.
Solid development.
Transposing toward Semi-Slav structures!
The Queen's Gambit Accepted. We take the pawn! It's not really a gambit - White will recover it.
White seizes the center.
We counter in the center!
White develops.
We open the position.
White prepares to recapture on c4.
We develop.
White recaptures.
We develop. Equal game.
The London System. White develops the bishop before e3. Very popular at club level but not theoretically dangerous.
THE BEST RESPONSE! We immediately strike at White's center. This is the most challenging line against the London.
White plays their standard setup.
We develop and pressure d4.
White reinforces d4.
THE KEY MOVE! We attack b2 and pressure d4. White must defend accurately.
White offers a queen trade.
We gain space and fix White's queenside! The c3 pawn is now backward.
Queen retreats.
We develop actively! Black has a pleasant position with queenside space.
We can also trade queens for an equal endgame.
White recaptures.
We trade. Equal endgame.
White recaptures.
We develop. Black is fine.
A passive retreat. We're already doing well.
We develop actively. Black is comfortable.
White defends b2.
We develop. If Qxf5?? then ...Qxb2 wins the rook.
Simple development also works well.
White develops.
An interesting idea! We challenge the London bishop.
White offers a trade.
We trade and eliminate White's pride - the London bishop!
Solid. We prepare ...Bd6 or ...Be7.
White develops.
We offer to trade the London bishop! After Bxd6 Qxd6, we have the bishop pair.
White trades.
We recapture. The London bishop is gone, and we have the bishop pair!
White retreats.
We castle. Good position for Black.
White develops the knight first.
Same idea - pressure on b2 and d4!
We can also open the position immediately.
White recaptures.
We kick the knight and the bishop! Gaining space.
White trades.
We recapture. The bishop must move.
Bishop retreats.
We develop. Black has excellent central control!
White reinforces d4 immediately.
We develop and pressure d4.
White plays their standard setup.
Same idea - attacking b2!
White takes. We recover the pawn easily.
We develop and will take back on c5.
White protects c5.
We attack the bishop and gain space! After Bg3 Bxc5, we've regained the pawn with a great position.
Also good - we can still play ...c5 next.
Standard London.
We challenge the center as usual. Transposes to main anti-London lines.
Mirroring White! A valid approach.
White plays c4.
Transposing to a Slav with Bf5 already out - exactly what we want!
White develops.
We challenge the center.
Flexible - White might play c4 (Queen's Gambit), Bf4 (London), or e3 (Colle).
We develop and wait to see White's plan.
Now it's the Queen's Gambit.
Back to our Slav! Main lines follow.
Or QGD if you prefer.
The London System.
We challenge the center as in our main anti-London.
The Colle System. White will play Bd3, c3, Nbd2 - a solid setup.
We develop the bishop actively! This is best against the Colle.
White develops.
We trade. Simple chess.
White recaptures.
We solidify. Equal position - we achieved our goal of developing the bishop.
White transposes to Queen's Gambit structures.
We go Slav! Bishop is already out - perfect.
We can also challenge the center immediately.
White plays Colle-Zukertort style.
We develop. Good position.
The Catalan! White fianchettoes. A dangerous weapon at high levels.
We develop the bishop! Against the Catalan, getting this bishop out is important.
White fianchettoes.
We solidify. Black is very comfortable with the active bishop.
White castles.
We develop. Preparing to castle with a solid position.
White plays c4.
We go for the Slav structure! Bishop is already out, mission accomplished.
We can also play Slav-style, keeping ...Bf5 in reserve.
White fianchettoes.
Now we bring out the bishop!
The Trompowsky Attack (with d5 already played). White develops the bishop aggressively.
We develop. If Bxf6, we get the bishop pair.
White takes.
We recapture toward the center. We have the bishop pair!
White develops.
We develop. Black will castle kingside despite the doubled pawns - they control the center!
White plays c4.
We reinforce the center. Solid position with the bishop pair.
Taking toward the center with g-pawn is also playable! We get an open g-file for attack.
White plays c4.
We develop. Black will play ...Bb4+ or ...Bd6 with good compensation.
White develops quietly.
We develop our bishop! Standard Slav approach.
We ask the bishop where it wants to go.
White maintains the bishop.
We go for a Slav structure.
White retreats to f4 - now it's a London!
We use our anti-London setup!
The Veresov Attack. An old-fashioned but playable system.
We develop.
The main Veresov setup.
We prepare ...e6 and avoid the pin being too annoying.
White develops.
We ask the bishop to decide.
White takes.
We recapture with the knight, keeping good structure. Black is fine.
We can also develop the bishop immediately - same Slav philosophy!
White takes.
We get the bishop pair! Good for Black.
White develops - transposes to other lines.
We develop the bishop!
A passive move, possibly heading for Stonewall Attack (f4) or just a quiet game.
We immediately develop the bishop! Against passive play, we grab space and activity.
White develops.
We trade.
White recaptures.
We develop. Black achieved the Slav goal - bishop developed before e6.
The Stonewall Attack!
We develop. Black is comfortable - our bishop is already active.
White develops.
We challenge the center! Black has a good game.
Also good - flexible.
White develops.
We develop the bishop actively!
The Indian Defense. Keeps options open for King's Indian, Nimzo-Indian, etc. A flexible alternative.
White grabs space.
Preparing ...Bb4 (Nimzo-Indian) or ...d5 (transposing to QGD).
White develops.
The Nimzo-Indian Defense! We pin the knight and control e4.
The Classical/Capablanca Variation. White avoids doubled pawns.
We castle. Very solid.
White asks the bishop to decide.
We give up the bishop pair but double White's pawns.
White recaptures.
We prepare ...Bb7, controlling the long diagonal. Typical Nimzo position.
The Rubinstein Variation. Solid but blocks the bishop.
We castle.
White develops.
We stake out the center. Classical play.
We can transpose to QGD/Semi-Slav structures.
QGD main lines.
Semi-Slav! We can still get our bishop out on f5 later.
White avoids the Nimzo-Indian.
The Queen's Indian Defense! We fianchetto to control e4.
White fianchettoes too.
We develop. Both sides have fianchettoed - typical Queen's Indian.
We can transpose to our main repertoire!
Transposes to QGD/Semi-Slav.
We go Slav!
Heading for the King's Indian Defense. A fighting choice!
White develops.
We fianchetto. The King's Indian is a fighting defense with rich tactical possibilities.
White seizes the center.
We prepare ...e5 or ...e7-e5. Classic King's Indian setup.
White develops.
We castle. Black will play ...e5, challenging the center.
The London System.
We transpose back to our main repertoire!
Standard London.
Our main anti-London! Same lines as before.
Flexible.
We can transpose to our Slav repertoire!
Queen's Gambit.
The Slav! Our main repertoire.
Keeping Indian options open.
